subject: probability
title: Central Limit Theorem Applications
contentHtml:
The Central Limit Theorem (CLT) is a cornerstone of probability theory, stating that the distribution of the sample mean will converge to a normal distribution as the sample size increases.

This has far-reaching implications for statistical inference and machine learning. In this card, we'll explore the applications of CLT in constructing confidence intervals and approximating binomial distributions.
intuition: The CLT allows us to make inferences about population means by analyzing the distribution of sample means. This is particularly useful when working with large datasets or performing hypothesis testing.
realWorldApplications: Constructing confidence intervals for A/B testing in machine learning

subject: probability
title: Central Limit Theorem Applications
contentHtml:
The Central Limit Theorem (CLT) is a cornerstone of probability theory, stating that the mean of a sufficiently large random sample from a population will be approximately normally distributed, even if the underlying distribution is not normal.

This has far-reaching implications for statistical inference and modeling. In this card, we'll explore two key applications: confidence intervals and the normal approximation to the binomial distribution.
intuition: The CLT allows us to make inferences about a population based on a sample of data. By assuming the sample mean is normally distributed, we can use standard normal tables or simulations to estimate population parameters like means and proportions.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, the CLT is used to justify the use of Gaussian distributions for modeling continuous variables.
commonMistakes: Failing to check assumptions before applying the CLT

subject: probability
statementHtml: Suppose we have a random variable X that follows a binomial distribution with parameters n and p. Construct a 95% confidence interval for the true proportion p using the central limit theorem (CLT).
hints: Start by applying the CLT to approximate the distribution of the sample mean.
Use the inverse normal distribution function to find the critical value.
The width of the confidence interval will depend on the sample size and the desired level of confidence.
solutionHtml:
To apply the CLT, we need to check if the conditions are met. Since n is large enough, we can assume that the sample mean follows a normal distribution.

Next, we find the critical value z using the inverse normal distribution function with a confidence level of 95%:

\[\text{z} = \Phi^{-1}(0.975) ≈ 1.96\]

The width of the confidence interval is then:

\[2 \cdot \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} \cdot z ≈ 2 \cdot \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} \cdot 1.96\]

Finally, we construct the confidence interval:

\[\text{CI} = \left(\bar{x} - 1.96 \cdot \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}, \bar{x} + 1.96 \cdot \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}\right)\]

subject: probability
statementHtml: Construct a 95% confidence interval for the true proportion of defective products in a random sample of size n.
hints: Start by determining the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.
Use the Central Limit Theorem to justify normal approximation.
Apply the formula for the margin of error.
solutionHtml:
To construct a 95% confidence interval, we first need to determine the z-score corresponding to our desired level of confidence.

\[z = \text{norm}^{-1}(0.975) ≈ 1.96.\]

Next, we calculate the standard deviation of the sampling distribution:

\[\sigma = \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}}.\]

Then, we apply the formula for the margin of error:

\[E = z \cdot \sigma ≈ 0.048.\]

Finally, we construct our confidence interval:

\[CI = (\hat{p} - E, \hat{p} + E).\]

subject: probability
statementHtml: Construct a 95% confidence interval for the true proportion p of students who prefer coffee over tea.
hints: The sample size is large enough to apply the Central Limit Theorem (CLT).
Use the normal approximation to the binomial distribution.
Round your answer to two decimal places.
solutionHtml:
To construct a 95% confidence interval, we need to find the Z-score corresponding to the desired confidence level:

\[Z = ext{invNorm}(0.975) ≈ 1.96.\]

Next, calculate the standard error:

\[SE = \sqrt{ rac{p̂(1-p̂)}{n}} ≈ √( rac{0.7(1-0.7)}{100}) ≈ 0.05.\]

Now, use the Z-score and standard error to find the critical value:

\[criticalValue = Z \cdot SE ≈ 1.96 \cdot 0.05 ≈ 0.098.\]

The confidence interval is then:

\[(p̂ - criticalValue, p̂ + criticalValue) = (0.7 - 0.098, 0.7 + 0.098) ≈ (0.602, 0.798).\]

",

subject: probability
statementHtml: Construct a 95% confidence interval for the true proportion p of students who prefer coffee over tea.
hints: Start by identifying the sample proportion &hat;p.
Recall that the standard error of the sample proportion is SE(&hat;p) = sqrt{&hat;p(1-&hat;p)/n}.
Use the Central Limit Theorem to justify the normal approximation.
solutionHtml:
To construct the confidence interval, we need to find the critical value Z corresponding to a 2.5th percentile of the standard normal distribution.

We can use a calculator or software to obtain Z ≈ -1.96.

The lower bound of the confidence interval is then given by:

\[&hat;p - Z \cdot SE(&hat;p) = 0.6 - 1.96 \cdot sqrt{0.6(1-0.6)/100} ≈ 0.512.\]

The upper bound is similarly calculated as:

\[&hat;p + Z \cdot SE(&hat;p) = 0.6 + 1.96 \cdot sqrt{0.6(1-0.6)/100} ≈ 0.688.\]
